chunks.chunk_text: This is a download from BBC Learning English. To find out more, visit our website. Hello, this is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I'm Neil. And I'm Georgina. Are you good at remembering your computer passwords, Georgina? Not really, Neil. I mostly use something easy to remember, like my mother's maiden name or the street where I was born.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Could you be a victim of online fraud_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Or the name of your first pet. Yes, me too. But we should be more careful about online security, Georgina, because of a worrying trend and the topic of this programme – online fraud. Online fraud involves using the internet to trick someone into giving away their money or data. It takes many forms, from deceptive emails which trick us into paying money, to the wrong bank account, to the theft of credit card details. It's regarded by some as a highly profitable and relatively low-risk crime.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Could you be a victim of online fraud_.json

chunks.chunk_text: So in this programme, we'll be finding out why it's so easy for criminals or fraudsters to steal our money. And of course, we'll be learning some related vocabulary along the way. But first, it's time for our quiz question.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Could you be a victim of online fraud_.json

chunks.chunk_text: It must be a lot, so I'll say... OK, Georgina, we'll find out later. Now, Rachel Tobak, CEO of Social Proof Security, is an expert in cybercrime. She describes herself as...
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Could you be a victim of online fraud_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Here, Rachel explains to BBC World Service programme The Inquiry how getting people's information is the key to online fraud.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Could you be a victim of online fraud_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Rachel looks at fraud from a criminal's mindset – someone's way of thinking and the general attitudes and opinions they have about something. From a fraudster's perspective, the most valuable thing is intelligence – secret information about a government or country, or in this case, a person, such as the information people unwittingly post on social media. Fraudsters use this intelligence to build up a picture of someone's online activity.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Could you be a victim of online fraud_.json

chunks.chunk_text: And as BBC World Service The Inquiry presenter Charmaine Kozier explains, there are many ways of doing this.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Could you be a victim of online fraud_.json

chunks.chunk_text: If people believe these cover stories and share personal data, this can result in a data breach – an occasion when private information can be seen by people who should not be able to see it.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Could you be a victim of online fraud_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Data, which is then used to infiltrate other online accounts, secretly enter a place, group or organisation in order to spy on it or influence it. Modern fraudsters are so devious at collecting online information that many victims only realise what's happened after their bank accounts have been emptied. Which I guess was the mindset behind those British fraudsters you mentioned earlier, Neil. Ah yes, the nine men who tried to defraud the coronavirus jobs retention scheme. Remember, for my quiz question, I asked you
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Could you be a victim of online fraud_.json

chunks.chunk_text: how much the scheme has paid out in total so far in the UK. I said a, £17 billion. Well, in fact, it's even more – the correct answer is b, £27 billion. Luckily, the £495,000 which these fraudsters tried to steal was recovered. Even so, Neil, I think I'm going to change my password soon. Better safe than sorry! Good idea, Georgina. In this programme, we've been hearing about the rise in online fraud.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Could you be a victim of online fraud_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Often committed when fraudsters gain intelligence – secret information about a person posted on the internet. By posing as clerks from your bank, for example, they might be able to access sensitive private information which they should not be able to see – an event sometimes called a data breach.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Could you be a victim of online fraud_.json

chunks.chunk_text: If you want to find out more about keeping yourself safe from online fraud, search the BBC website using the term cyber security.
